body: @dubeejw why you close this issue?
@csantanapr - he closed it because he merged the fix in already.

@jasonpet Thanks for the info. @dubeejw When we close issues because the PR is merged, It's good to add a message like "closing merged with commit xxxxxxx"  this way give reason but also can find the commit that fixed the issue, then we can track when it makes it to production.

@jasonpet What's the PR that fixed this issue? I was not able to see a mentioned reference here.

Yes I know I know, if I look very hard I eventually will find it ðŸ˜ƒ
PR - https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/951
Fixes #946
Merged as e4770a330ceac0ab0272ec975a366ec8cc92a097
[Ready for merge] @starpit Please review and merge if all looks ok, thanks.

@jasonpet, looks good. Can you rebase?
Don't forget to update the documentation (catalog.md)

I'm not sure that we need a complex test for null - here's a suggested alternative:

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/compare/master...rabbah:pr-906?expand=1

in particular this commit https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/fadebede97fc9985f33a8034bc9d222f0a44bd7d simplifies an existing test to just be the echo action and passed in a value null and confirms it is returned as expected. Is this sufficient to test the fix in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/cc16d6f8b695073652abb0d4c81dc0bdc0906ea7.
cli tests for the corner cases (create action and get limits sufficient to make sure covered)?
I've tried to use this to reproduce #926 but so far no dice. @psuter are you making any changes to this request or do you consider it ready?
After looking more, the problem lies in the gradle.sh file in 'tools/ubuntu-setup'.  Here is the error "Unable to locate package gradle-2.7".  Going to keep poking and updating...

Try changing gradle.sh:

```
diff --git a/tools/ubuntu-setup/gradle.sh b/tools/ubuntu-setup/gradle.sh
index 019efae..e3e9e18 100755
--- a/tools/ubuntu-setup/gradle.sh
+++ b/tools/ubuntu-setup/gradle.sh
@@ -3,5 +3,5 @@ sudo apt-get install -y python-software-properties
 sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:cwchien/gradle 
 sudo apt-get update -y
 sudo apt-cache search gradle 
-sudo apt-get install -y gradle-2.7 
+sudo apt-get install -y gradle-2.11
```

@markusthoemmes @csantanapr can't we boostrap `gradlew` and eschew the need for this prereq install?
Yea, i bumped to 2.10 and it worked.  Should I put a patch in to update the version, or is this going to make you guys go another route for installing?
@rabbah i noted in a different issue that gradle doesn't need to be installed at all as you mentioned.
@tommyk looks like we will just remove this file to avoid the hiccup in the future.
Fixed by #918.
As @rabbah mentioned, warnings are in place (as of #642). @csantanapr close?

The status code returned by an invoke is covered by #645.
To generate a message in the wsk activation poll, if the result of the activation is an error, it could be printed to the console. This would be the last remaining bit from the items listed in this issue.
We should also ignore the test in Swift3ActionContainerTests in tests/src/actionContainers

@mdeuser, ready for review.

Tests look good on first pass - one tip: rather than repeating the annotation/parameter json in several test, you could lift them into a function - same for the checks/regex matches. On the latter, there might be a helper which will turn the wsk cli response into a json object which will then allow you to just do JsValue equality (much simpler).
Thanks @jasonpet for the heads up,  I will update the docs in this PR then.

@csantanapr proposed patch: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/compare/master...rabbah:gradlew?expand=1

we should use this issue to drive the vagrant ci (which would have caught the bit rot).

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33234665/upgrading-setuptools-on-osx-el-capitan

sudo pip install paramiko PyYAML Jinja2 httplib2 six --user python

@markusthoemmes @psuter  - If the python CLI did not have this check, would some of the automated tests have failed?   In the Go CLI case, the automated tests have not been failing, so I'm wondering if that is sufficient enough validation that the Go CLI output does not include the special terminal code characters when invoked outside a terminal window.
Squashed rebased and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/f0dab306bd8e7bfc9fcafde0467af985940131c9.
@mdeuser I thought it was clear what happens (ie the logs are truncated even with 0MB) - do you have suggested alternative language?
Since a 0MB log size limit is an unusual setting, I thought it might need explicit doc.  In other products, I've seen the use of 0 to mean "unlimited".
This work is completed and merged.  The various counts are now reset and this was tested at least once by @markusthoemmes in a deployed system.

If a client app is developed and it's interface to the backend if emitting (firing) events/triggers then the client app will not be able to retrieve the results for the trigger that got fired. 

The benefit of using a trigger is the abstraction via rule, so client side doesn't need to know the name of the action, and the rule controls the abstraction.
@rabbah please review and merge.

Looking at the following code snippet from `convertArgumentInputToJSON()`:

```
        if ((len(args[i + 1]) > 0) && (isValidJSON(args[i + 1]) || (args[i + 1][0] == '[' && args[i + 1][len(args[i + 1]) - 1] == ']') ||
        (args[i + 1][0] == '"' && args[i + 1][len(args[i + 1]) - 1] == '"'))) {
```

it might be more clear to use regex patterns for the [xxx] and "xxx" tests

Minor restructure comment:  combine the above condition tests with the Atoi() condition test to reduce code (i.e. drop additional `else`, remove the extra `res = res +` statement)
@rabbah please review

@ChrBi I review the changes, please address at your convenience
@aliolci thanks for the pointer, ansible problems where related to ubunutu and got foxed by switching to use apt-get on ubuntu

@mdeuser, in regard to your comment about the invalid JSON error message, all invalid JSON will be assumed to be a string now. That means there will no longer be an error message for invalid JSON. This mimics the behavior of the Python CLI.
`sudo apt-get install -y ansible=2.1.0.0-1*` might be the stop gap; for vagrant this installs version `2.1.0.0-1ppa~trusty`.
@lehoanganh @domdom82 can we upgrade required ansible to at least v2.1.0.0? the latest release might fix #632 but requires other changes to our playbooks.
@ChrBi @markusthoemmes a few changes for your review.

vagrant is calling source all.sh under ubuntu setup. 
sudo apt-get install -y ansible=2.1.0.0-1\* and 2.1.0.0-1ppa~trusty do not work well. It always shows unable to find ansible=2.1.0.0-1\* or 2.1.0.0-1ppa~trusty.

After adding the following:
sudo apt-get install -y software-properties-common
sudo apt-add-repository -y ppa:ansible/ansible
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y ansible=2.0.2.0-1ppa~trusty

sudo apt-get install -y ansible=2.0.2.0-1ppa~trusty does not work.

pip can work well in installing 2.1.0.0.

@mdeuser @dubeejw note and review the changes in restructuring the basic cli tests - i moved some out of the system package and into a new cli test package intended to test basic operations and corner cases using the cli. not all of the tests in the latter can run without a deployed backend (yet).
Great job, looks good to me modulo comments.

I'm trying the latest version. The drawback of pinned version with apt-get is, the Ansible team delete the old version once they publish the new version in the repo. We were also facing this problem in the past where the pinned version was not found via apt-get.
so the pip path while results in a longer install step might be best in general?
or we can pin the version, if the problem occurs again, fix it with the new version. With such process, we can control the installed version.

An example for you
https://travis-ci.org/lehoanganh/openwhisk/builds/148289322

Try this pull: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/968/files

```
E: Version '2.1.0.0-1*' for 'ansible' was not found
```

```
lha@ubuntu î‚° ~ î‚° sudo apt-cache policy ansible
ansible:
  Installed: (none)
  Candidate: 2.1.1.0-1ppa~trusty
  Version table:
     2.1.1.0-1ppa~trusty 0
        500 http://ppa.launchpad.net/ansible/ansible/ubuntu/ trusty/main amd64 Packages
     1.7.2+dfsg-1~ubuntu14.04.1 0
        100 http://us.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ trusty-backports/universe amd64 Packages
     1.5.4+dfsg-1 0
        500 http://us.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ trusty/universe amd64 Packages
```

`2.1.0.0-1` was deleted from repo
so pip install 2.0.2.0 or 2.1.0.0?
`pip install --user ansible==2.0.2.0` worked. https://travis-ci.org/lehoanganh/openwhisk/builds/148293667
`2.1.1.0-1` (latest) didn't work, maybe syntax changes in `setup.yml` which does not like other ansible version greater than 2.0.2.0.
i think this one is closable now that #893 has been merged?

Reverted to using pip.

Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/36ad900f7a81cb835e732529a5f0a69429067dd3.

Travis restored by pinning to earlier version. Leaving this issue open to address upgrade to latest ansible. Also going to close #632 as duplicate of this since latest ansible contains the fix for spaces in path.

team members with Windows computers are working with Vagrant using new share folder flow. If you see problems in Windows please open a new issue.

@mdeuser I split the tests based on what criteria and invariant were being checked. Basic usage, testing parameter corner cases,  validity of arguments and the like I put in the new suite. Tests which are verifying the CRUD+activate life cycles or package operations I left in the `system` package. We can evolve a better criteria for where to locate CLI tests.

Related to #512.

Currently when a trigger matches a rule, the `caused` property of the rule activation will be the trigger's activation id. However, when the activator was re-architected, we lost the causality tracking between the rule and the action - so that the `caused` property in the action activation is empty (always). The activation of actions via rules will require some more inlining vs the current implementation - at which point the causality between the rule and the action can be restored.

@lfzCarlosC this is now addressed. 
Please give it a try and provide feedback
